{
  "content": "L1: package adapter
L2: 
L3: import (
L4: 	"errors"
L5: 	"strings"
L6: 
L7: 	"github.com/loom/loom/internal/adapter/anthropic"
L8: 	"github.com/loom/loom/internal/adapter/ollama"
L9: 	"github.com/loom/loom/internal/adapter/openai"
L10: 	responses "github.com/loom/loom/internal/adapter/openai/responses"
L11: 	"github.com/loom/loom/internal/adapter/openrouter"
L12: 	"github.com/loom/loom/internal/engine"
L13: )
L14: 
L15: // Provider represents the type of LLM provider.
L16: type Provider string
L17: 
L18: const (
L19: 	// OpenAI provider (e.g., GPT-4o)
L20: 	ProviderOpenAI Provider = "openai"
L21: 
L22: 	// Anthropic provider (e.g., Claude)
L23: 	ProviderAnthropic Provider = "anthropic"
L24: 
L25: 	// Ollama provider for local models
L26: 	ProviderOllama Provider = "ollama"
L27: 
L28: 	// OpenRouter provider for multi-model access
L29: 	ProviderOpenRouter Provider = "openrouter"
L30: )
L31: 
L32: // Config holds configuration for an LLM adapter.
L33: type Config struct {
L34: 	Provider Provider
L35: 	Model    string
L36: 	APIKey   string
L37: 	Endpoint string // For custom endpoints (e.g., Azure OpenAI or Ollama)
L38: }
L39: 
L40: // DefaultConfig returns a conservative default configuration.
L41: func DefaultConfig() Config {
L42: 	// Default to OpenAI
L43: 	config := Config{
L44: 		Provider: ProviderOpenAI,
L45: 		Model:    "gpt-4o",
L46: 	}
L47: 
L48: 	return config
L49: }
L50: 
L51: // New creates a new LLM adapter based on configuration.
L52: func New(config Config) (engine.LLM, error) {
L53: 	switch config.Provider {
L54: 	case ProviderOpenAI:
L55: 		if config.APIKey == "" {
L56: 			return nil, errors.New("openai API key not set; set it in Settings")
L57: 		}
L58: 		// Prefer Responses API for o-series and gpt-5 models, or when explicitly requested
L59: 		useResponses := false
L60: 		m := strings.ToLower(strings.TrimSpace(config.Model))
L61: 		if strings.HasPrefix(m, "o3") || strings.HasPrefix(m, "o4") || strings.HasPrefix(m, "gpt-5") {
L62: 			useResponses = true
L63: 		}
L64: 		// Environment toggle removed; rely on model prefix to choose responses client
L65: 		if useResponses {
L66: 			return responses.New(config.APIKey, config.Model), nil
L67: 		}
L68: 		return openai.New(config.APIKey, config.Model), nil
L69: 
L70: 	case ProviderAnthropic:
L71: 		if config.APIKey == "" {
L72: 			return nil, errors.New("anthropic API key not set; set it in Settings")
L73: 		}
L74: 		return anthropic.New(config.APIKey, config.Model), nil
L75: 
L76: 	case ProviderOllama:
L77: 		baseURL := config.Endpoint
L78: 		if baseURL == "" {
L79: 			baseURL = "http://localhost:11434/v1/chat/completions"
L80: 		}
L81: 		return ollama.New(baseURL, config.Model), nil
L82: 
L83: 	case ProviderOpenRouter:
L84: 		if config.APIKey == "" {
L85: 			return nil, errors.New("openrouter API key not set; set it in Settings")
L86: 		}
L87: 		return openrouter.New(config.APIKey, config.Model), nil
L88: 
L89: 	default:
L90: 		return nil, errors.New("unknown LLM provider")
L91: 	}
L92: }
L93: 
L94: // Removed safeSubstring helper and debug prints
L95: ",

{
  "content": "L1: [![CI](https://github.com/TimAnthonyAlexander/loom/actions/workflows/tests.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/TimAnthonyAlexander/loom/actions/workflows/tests.yml)
L2: 
L3: [Deutsche Version](README_DE.md)
L4: 
L5: Modern, code-aware, desktop AI assistant with an extensible tool system, built with Go (Wails) and React (Vite) using Material UI. Loom is a ground‚Äëup rewrite of Loom v1 focused on simplicity, extensibility, reliability, and a calm, content‚Äëcentric UX.
L6: 
L7: ## Overview
L8: Loom pairs a Go orchestrator and tooling layer with a modern React UI. It‚Äôs designed for iterative coding assistance on local projects with first‚Äëclass support for:
L9: - Semantically exploring code
L10: - Precise, minimal file edits with human approval
L11: - Streaming responses, reasoning snippets, and tool calls
L12: - Clean separation between engine, adapters, tools, and UI
L13: 
L14: ## Screenshots
L15: 
L16: Some screenshots of the interface and Loom in action:
L17: 
L18: ![Loom Screenshot](screenshot1.png)
L19: ![Loom Screenshot](screenshot2.png)
L20: ![Loom Screenshot](screenshot3.png)
L21: ![Loom Screenshot](screenshot4.png)
L22: 
L23: ## Key features
L24: - Desktop app via Wails: native windowing, compact packaging, and system integration
L25: - Material UI: minimalist, content‚Äëforward interface with a calm visual rhythm
L26: - Tool registry: explicit tool registration with schemas and safety flags
L27: - Providers: OpenAI, Anthropic Claude, OpenRouter (thousands of models), and local Ollama adapters
L28: - Semantic search: ripgrep‚Äëbacked search with structured results
L29: - Heuristic symbol indexing: SQLite + FTS search over project symbols with tools for definitions, references, outlines, and neighborhood slices
L30: - Safe editing: proposed edits with diff preview and explicit approval before apply
L31: - Project memory: workspace‚Äëscoped persistence for stable, predictable state
L32: - Shell execution: propose/approve/execute commands with stdout/stderr capture; cwd confined to the workspace
L33: - Auto‚Äëapproval: optional automatic approval for edits and shell commands
L34: - Rules system: user and project‚Äëspecific rules for consistent AI behavior
L35: - Tabbed editor: Monaco with theme, Cmd/Ctrl+S to save, and file explorer
L36: - Reasoning view: transient, collapsible stream of model reasoning summaries
L37: - Cost tracking: See all tokens spent on which project, model, input/output
L38: 
L39: ## Architecture
L40: - Frontend (`ui/frontend/`)
L41:   - Vite + React 18 + TypeScript
L42:   - Material UI components and Catppuccin theme for Monaco
L43:   - Markdown rendering with code highlighting
L44:   - Streaming message updates via Wails events
L45:   - Approval dialog with diff formatting
L46: 
L47: - Backend (`ui/main.go` and `internal/*`)
L48:   - Wails app bootstraps engine, tools, adapters, and memory
L49:   - Engine orchestrates model calls and tool invocations
L50:   - Tool registry declares available capabilities and safety
L51:   - Adapters implement provider‚Äëspecific chat semantics
L52:   - Memory stores project data under the workspace path
L53:   - Indexer performs fast code search via ripgrep
L54: 
L55: - Website (`web/`) https://loom-assistant.de
L56:   - Vite + React 18 + TypeScript
L57:   - Material UI components
L58:   - Marketing and Landing Page
L59: 
L60: ## Directory structure
L61: - `ui/` ‚Äî Wails app (Go) and frontend
L62: - `internal/` ‚Äî engine, adapters, tools, memory, indexer, config
L63: - `web/` ‚Äî website (marketing, landing page)
L64: - `Makefile` ‚Äî common dev/build tasks
L65: 
L66: ## Getting started
L67: Prerequisites:
L68: - Go 1.21+
L69: - Node.js 18+ and npm
L70: - ripgrep (`rg`) on PATH
L71: - Platform toolchain (e.g., Xcode Command Line Tools on macOS)
L72: 
L73: Install all dependencies:
L74: 
L75: ```bash
L76: make deps
L77: ```
L78: 
L79: This will:
L80: - Tidy Go modules and install the Wails CLI
L81: - Install frontend dependencies (including Material UI)
L82: - Ensure ripgrep is available (installs via Homebrew on macOS if missing)
L83: 
L84: ## Running and building
L85: - Development (full app with Wails live reload):
L86:   ```bash
L87:   make dev-hmr
L88:   ```
L89: - Frontend only (Vite dev server):
L90:   ```bash
L91:   cd ui/frontend && npm run dev
L92:   ```
L93: - Build (current platform):
L94:   ```bash
L95:   make build
L96:   ```
L97: - Platform builds:
L98:   - macOS universal: `make build-macos-universal`
L99:   - macOS per‚Äëarch: `make build-macos-amd64` (intel), `make build-macos-arm64` (apple silicon)
L100:   - Windows: `make build-windows`
L101:   - Linux: `make build-linux-all` (or `build-linux-amd64` / `build-linux-arm64`)
L102: 
L103: ## Configuration
L104: Loom configures an LLM adapter via the adapter factory (`internal/adapter/factory.go`) with conservative defaults
L105: 
L106: API keys and endpoints are managed in‚Äëapp via Settings and persisted to `~/.loom/settings.json`. By design, the app prefers persisted settings over environment variables.
L107: 
L108: - OpenAI: set your key in Settings (stored as `openai_api_key`)
L109: - Anthropic: set your key in Settings (stored as `anthropic_api_key`)
L110: - OpenRouter: set your key in Settings (stored as `openrouter_api_key`) for access to thousands of models
L111: - Ollama: set endpoint in Settings (stored as `ollama_endpoint`), e.g. `http://localhost:11434/v1/chat/completions`
L112: 
L113: ### Settings
L114: Settings include:
L115: - Last workspace path and last selected model (`provider:model_id`)
L116: - Feature flags:
L117:   - Auto‚Äëapprove Shell
L118:   - Auto‚Äëapprove Edits
L119: 
L120: Settings are saved to `~/.loom/settings.json` with restrictive permissions.
L121: 
L122: ### Rules
L123: Two rule sets influence model behavior:
L124: - User Rules: global (stored at `~/.loom/rules.json`)
L125: - Project Rules: workspace‚Äëspecific (stored at `<workspace>/.loom/rules.json`)
L126: 
L127: Access Rules from the sidebar. The app normalizes and persists rule arrays.
L128: 
L129: ### Model selection
L130: The UI exposes a comprehensive model selector with both curated static models and dynamically fetched models. Entries are of the form `provider:model_id` and grouped by provider and capabilities.
L131: 
L132: **Static Models**: The interface includes curated selections of flagship models from OpenAI (GPT-5, o3, o4-mini), Anthropic Claude (Opus 4, Sonnet 4, Haiku 4, 3.5 Sonnet, etc.), and local Ollama models (Llama, Mistral, DeepSeek R1, etc.).
L133: 
L134: **Dynamic OpenRouter Models**: When you configure an OpenRouter API key, the interface automatically fetches the complete catalog of available models with real-time pricing information. This provides access to thousands of models from various providers including:
L135: - Latest frontier models from all major providers
L136: - Specialized models for different tasks
L137: - Cost-effective alternatives with transparent pricing
L138: - Models sorted by cost efficiency
L139: 
L140: **Model Categories**: Models are organized into logical groups:
L141: - **Flagship**: Top-tier models for complex tasks
L142: - **Reasoning**: Models optimized for step-by-step thinking
L143: - **Fast**: Quick response models for simple tasks  
L144: - **Cheap**: Cost-effective models for high-volume usage
L145: - **OpenRouter**: Dynamic catalog with pricing
L146: 
L147: The backend parses `provider:model_id` (see `internal/adapter/models.go`) and switches adapters accordingly. OpenRouter models use the format `openrouter:provider/model-name`.
L148: 
L149: ## Using Loom
L150: - Workspace: choose a workspace on first launch or via the sidebar. The file explorer and Monaco editor reflect the active workspace.
L151: - Model selection: in the Chat panel header, pick a model. The choice is persisted and sent to the backend (`SetModel`).
L152: - Conversations:
L153:   - Start a new conversation from the Chat panel
L154:   - Attach files to the message using the Attach Button or CTRL+ALT+P (CMD+OPTION+P on macOS)
L155:   - Recent conversations appear when the thread is empty; select to load
L156:   - Clearing chat creates a fresh conversation
L157: - Messages and streaming:
L158:   - Events: `chat:new`, `assistant-msg` (assistant stream), `assistant-reasoning` (reasoning stream), `task:prompt` (approval), `system:busy`
L159:   - Reasoning stream shows transient summaries; it auto‚Äëcollapses after completion
L160: - Editor:",
  "language": "markdown",
  "lines": 311,
  "path": "README.md",
  "symbols_summary": "Symbols: showing 0 of 0 in this file. Use tools: symbols_search, symbols_def, symbols_refs, symbols_neighborhood, symbols_outline."
}
